messageBody:
Dear all,

I'm in the process of adapting QuickScript for Dutch. I'm aware that one participant in this group has proposed a Dutch version of QuickScript, but uhm, IMNSHO, it could do with a little improvement.

Since I'm not a linguist, I thought it would be a good idea to write down my findings and opinions early, and hopefully get some valuable feedback from the group.

Best regards,
Pieter (pronounced /pitər/)


CONSONANTS FREQUENCIES
There is a number of remarkable differences is consonant frequencies that I think should be taken into consideration.
  • Dutch completely lacks the English /θ/, /ð/ and // w(#7 and #8).
  • The phonemes /g/, /ʃ/, /tʃ/, and /dʒ/ (#6, #13, #15 and #16), while common in English, are rare in Dutch, occuring almost exclusively in loanwords, as in "goal", "shock", "check" and "gel".
  • The phoneme /ʒ/ (#14) seems to be rare in both languages. In Dutch it only occurs in loanwords, like "journaal".
  • English completely lacks phonemes /ɣ/ and /x/ (which are very common in Dutch and make us sound like Klingons. Read invented the letter "lo-CH" to be able to write Scottish names, but given the high frequency of /ɣ/ and /x/ in Dutch I suggest a more versatile character be used.
    • The "lo-CH" letter always starts "tall" and ends on the lower parallel, which would cause frequent penlifts for Dutch writers.
    • /ɣ/ is most frequently preceded by /ə/ and /ɔʊ/, and followed by /ə/, /r/, /eɪ/ and /ɪ/.
    • /x/ is most frequently preceded by /ɑ/, /ɛ/ and /s/ (eg. in the infamous word "Scheveningen"), and followed by a /t/ or /r/. The combination /sxr/ (as in "schrijven") is particularly frequent.
CONSONANT USE
In Dutch, consonants at the end of a word are (almost) always voiceless, even if they stem from (and are written as) a voiced consonant. For example: "bod" /bɔt/, "eb" /ɛp/, "maag" /maːx/. In English, voiced consonants at word endings are common, as in "stub", "naked" (and many other words ending with "-ed"), "dig", "love", "was" and "page". This remarkable difference could be taken into consideration. Eg. Read designed is alphabet such that voiced consonants /b/, /d/ and /z/ are particularly easy to write at word endings, using the alternative character for #2, #4 and #12 respectively. Note particularly the plural /z/ at the end of many English plurals, eg. "berries".

VOWELS
In consonants, there's enough overlap between Dutch and English to make QuickScript suitable for Dutch without major changes. consonants, so Dutch has a lot more vowels than English. Many of the vowels in English do not occur in Dutch. WhereQuickScript provides us with Depending on who you ask, Dutch has anywhere between 16 and 28+ vowels.
  • Most linguists seem to agree that Dutch has the following monophthongs:
    /ɪ/ "kip"
    /i/ "biet"
    /ʏ/ "hut"
    /y/ "fuut"
    /ə/ "de"
    /ɑ/ "bad"
    /aː/ "zaad"
    /ɔ/ "bot"
    /u/ "hoed"
  • Additionally, the following phonemes are considered monophthongs or diphthongs, depending on who you ask and/or where you live.
    /eː/ "beet"
    /øː/ "neus"
    /oː/ "boot"
    According to IPA, these are monophthongs. In Belgium, these vowels indeed seem to have this monophthong quality, but in the Netherlands, particularly in the north, these vowels sound more like /eɪ/, /øy/ and /ɔʊ/ respectively.
  • Then, according to IPA, there are the following diphthongs:
    /ɛi/ "ei"
    /œy/ "ui"
    /ʌu/ "zout"
Apart from these 16 vowels, I hear a lot of other distinct vowel sounds in Dutch. Here my lack of linguistic schooling acts up, but I guess these are generally considered "allophones" of the primary 16 vowels, as follows:
  • /a/ or /ɐ/ "kameel". an allophone of /aː/, occuring in unstressed syllables.
  • /ɪ:/ "keren"; an allophone of /eː/ "beet". Both /ɪ:/ and /eː/ are considered expressions of the morpheme "lange e" ("long e"). The consonant following the vowel determine which allophone is to be pronounced. Note the difference in meaning between "kirren" /kɪrən/ and "keren" /kɪːrən/.
  • /ɔː/ "hoor"; an allophone of /oː/ "boot". Again, the consonant(s) following the vowel determines which allophone is used.
  • /ʏː/ "keur"; an allophone of /øː/ "keus". Again, the consonant(s) following the vowel determines which allophone is used.
Finally, Dutch has a number of vowels that are used rarely, and (almost?) exclusively in French loanwords:
  • /œː/ "oeuvre"; also commonly pronounced as /ʏː/ "keur".
  • /ɔ~/ "caisson"; almost identical to /ɔ/ "bot".
  • /ɛ~/ "electricien"; also commonly pronounced as /ɛn/ "en"
  • /ɑ~/ "restaurant"; almost identical to /ɑ/ "bad".
  • /œ~/ "parfum".
After having stared at Read's solutions to the intricacies of English vowel pronunciation a bit, and after trying to meaningfully map Dutch vowels onto Read's vowels and corresponding letters, I cannot but decide that Dutch is so much different from English, that it requires a different approach altogether. AFAICS, Read's original approach, with a purely phonetic spelling and almost completely eliminating multigrams, is simply not feasible for the Dutch language. The number of graphemes required would be inconcievably large.

The solution I'd like to propose is to map Dutch _phonemes_ on QuickScript characters, instead of _phones_. From what I've read over the last few days, "phonetic vs. phonemic vs. morphemic" is subject of a heated debate among spelling reformers to-be. Read clearly took the "phonetic" point of view, although some of the characters actually seem to represent phonemes rather than phones. I'd like to suggest that we take this a few steps further in the Dutch version of QuickScript. First, I don't think we have a choice; second, there have been extensive spelling reforms in Dutch already, which already succesfully addressed many of the problems in current English. In these reforms, a morphemic approach seem to have been taken, and this is what Dutch writers are used to already.
In fact, I think many Dutch speakers don't even realize that the "long e" morpheme is pronounced differently in "peer" /pɪːr/ and "peen" /peːn/. To most of us, it just sounds like a "long e", and it requires careful listening to hear that it can in fact be vocalized in two different ways. I'm convinced that it would be highly counter-intuitive for most Dutch writers if different graphemes be used for _ee_ in "peer" and "peen".

Looking at vowel frequencies, there's another important difference between English and Dutch: in English, the most frequent phonemes are /ɪ/ (9.9%), /i/ (5.0%), /ə/ (3.4%) and /ɑ/ (3.3%). In Dutch, the most frequent morphemes are /ə/ (11.7%), /ɑ/ (4.8%), /ɛ/ (3.7%) and /aː/ (3.6%). Percentages depend on what is counted, dialect, corpus etc., but for this discussion any generally accepted frequency distribution suffices, I think.
In short, the most frequent Dutch phoneme (/ə/) by far is only takes third place in the English frequency distribution. And vice versa, the most common phoneme in English by far (/ɪ/) takes fifth place in the Dutch frequency distribution. This might be taken into consideration when designing a Dutch QuickScript.

I'm gonna leave it at this for now. I already have a first version of a new Dutch QuickScript mapping, but I'd rather not release it yet.

Best regards,
Pieter

      <li>/œ~/ "parfum".<br>
      </li>
    </ul>
    After having stared at Read's solutions to the intricacies of
    English vowel pronunciation a bit, and after trying to meaningfully
    map Dutch vowels onto Read's vowels and corresponding letters, I
    cannot but decide that Dutch is so much different from English, that
    it requires a different approach altogether. AFAICS, Read's original
    approach, with a purely phonetic spelling and almost completely
    eliminating multigrams, is simply not feasible for the Dutch
    language. The number of graphemes required would be inconcievably
    large.<br>
    <br>
    The solution I'd like to propose is to map Dutch _phonemes_ on
    QuickScript characters, instead of _phones_. From what I've read
    over the last few days, "phonetic vs. phonemic vs. morphemic" is
    subject of a heated debate among spelling reformers to-be. Read
    clearly took the "phonetic" point of view, although some of the
    characters actually seem to represent phonemes rather than phones.
    I'd like to suggest that we take this a few steps further in the
    Dutch version of QuickScript. First, I don't think we have a choice;
    second, there have been extensive spelling reforms in Dutch already,
    which already succesfully addressed many of the problems in current
    English. In these reforms, a morphemic approach seem to have been
    taken, and this is what Dutch writers are used to already.<br>
    In fact, I think many Dutch speakers don't even realize that the
    "long e" morpheme is pronounced differently in "peer" /pɪːr/ and
    "peen" /peːn/. To most of us, it just sounds like a "long e", and it
    requires careful listening to hear that it can in fact be vocalized
    in two different ways. I'm convinced that it would be highly
    counter-intuitive for most Dutch writers if different graphemes be
    used for _ee_ in "peer" and "peen".<br>
    <br>
    Looking at vowel frequencies, there's another important difference
    between English and Dutch: in English, the most frequent phonemes
    are /ɪ/ (9.9%), /i/ (5.0%), /ə/ (3.4%) and /ɑ/ (3.3%). In Dutch, the
    most frequent morphemes are /ə/ (11.7%), /ɑ/ (4.8%), /ɛ/ (3.7%) and
    /aː/ (3.6%). Percentages depend on what is counted, dialect, corpus
    etc., but for this discussion any generally accepted frequency
    distribution suffices, I think.<br>
    In short, the most frequent Dutch phoneme (/ə/) by far is only takes
    third place in the English frequency distribution. And vice versa,
    the most common phoneme in English by far (/ɪ/) takes fifth place in
    the Dutch frequency distribution. This might be taken into
    consideration when designing a Dutch QuickScript.<br>
    <br>
    I'm gonna leave it at this for now. I already have a first version
    of a new Dutch QuickScript mapping, but I'd rather not release it
    yet.<br>
    <br>
    Best regards,<br>
    Pieter<br>
